Section.Name: Keyless Entry System
Section.TextContent: KEYLESS ENTRY SYSTEM

HotSpot.TextContent: Lock
• Push once to lock all doors.
• Push twice (within five seconds) for horn sound verification that all doors are locked.
Unlock
• Push once to unlock driver’s door or all the doors (depending on personalization setting*).
• Push twice (within three seconds) to unlock all doors.
Panic Alarm
• Push for one second or more to activate alarm.
• Push Lock, Unlock, or Panic Alarm to turn alarm off.

Section.TextContent: Back of Key

HotSpot.TextContent: Emergency Vehicle Entry:
If the key cannot be used due to a malfunction or dead key battery, use the auxiliary key to lock or unlock the doors.

• Make sure vehicle is OFF and take the keyless entry system key with you when leaving the vehicle. There is no warning if the IGN is ON or ACC is ON and the key is taken out of the vehicle, OR if the key is locked inside the vehicle.

• When locking doors using inside door switches or inside door-lock knobs, be careful not to leave the key inside the vehicle. With Advanced Keyless, there is a recognizable beep sound to alert you that the key is inside the vehicle.
• The RED Key Indicator Light may illuminate if either advance key or keyless entry key is placed in the cup holder. The key can sometimes not be detected in the cup holder.

Section.Name: Advanced Keyless Entry System
Section.TextContent: Available on Touring and Grand Touring.
ADVANCED KEYLESS ENTRY SYSTEM

HotSpot.TextContent: The Advanced Keyless Entry system improves convenience by allowing you to perform the following functions without taking the key out of your pocket or purse:
• Lock or unlock the doors
• Lock or unlock the trunk/liftgate
• Turn the engine on or off

Section.TextContent: What is Advanced Keyless Entry? Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: While Carrying the Advanced Key…
• Unlock the driver’s door by pushing the driver’s door request switch once.
• Unlock all doors by pushing the driver’s door request switch once or twice (depending on personalization setting) OR by pushing the passenger’s door request switch once.
• Lock all doors by pushing any request switch once.
Lock or Unlock the liftgate by pushing the request switch while carring the advanced key.

• Vehicles equipped with the Advanced Keyless Entry System and the Keyless Entry System both use the same type of keyless entry transmitter. However, only vehicles equipped with the Advanced Keyless Entry System allow you to lock and unlock the doors with the door request switches.
• Vehicles equipped with the Keyless Entry System do not have request switches on the doors/liftgate. To lock and unlock the doors, the corresponding transmitter button must be pushed.

Section.Name: Starting the Engine
Section.TextContent: STARTING (AND STOPPING) THE ENGINE WITH START/STOP BUTTON
Starting the Engine. Select START.
Stopping the Engine. Select STOP.

HotSpot.TextContent: While Carrying the Key•
• Start the engine by pushing the START/STOP button while pushing the clutch pedal (manual transmission) or the brake pedal (automatic transmission).
• Activate Accessories (ACC) by pushing the START/STOP button once without pushing the clutch or brake pedal.
• Turn the ignition to the ON position by pushing the START/STOP button twice without pushing the clutch or brake pedal.

• The key indicator light in the will show GREEN (engine ready to start) when the key is detected and the clutch pedal (M/T) or the brake pedal (A/T) is pushed. If the KEY warning light illuminates RED, or the START/STOP button indicator light flashes AMBER, this could indicate a problem with the engine starting system and the inability to start the engine or switch the ignition to ACC or ON. Have your vehicle inspected at an Authorized Mazda Dealer as soon as possible.
• The RED Key Indicator Light may flash if the key is placed in the cup holder. The key may not be detected in the cup holder.
Emergency Engine Start:
If the engine cannot be started due to a dead key battery:
1 Push the brake pedal (A/T) or the clutch pedal (M/T).
2 While the indicator light flashes GREEN, touch the START/STOP button using the back side of the transmitter (as shown).
3 After the GREEN indicator light illuminates constantly, push the START/STOP button with your finger to start the engine.
• Shut the engine OFF by setting the parking brake/placing the vehicle in Park (automatic transmission), then push the START/STOP button.
Emergency Engine Stop:
Pushing and holding the START/STOP button or repeatedly pushing the button while the engine is running will turn the engine OFF. Use only in case of an emergency.

Section.Name: Accelerated Warm-Up System
Section.TextContent: ACCELERATED WARM-UP SYSTEM (AWS)
What is AWS? Select the hotspots below.

HotSpot.TextContent: Your vehicle is equipped with SKYACTIV combustion technology. This technology includes AWS (Accelerated Warm-up System) for optimal emission performance during cold starting conditions.

On start-up, the engine speed and sound are higher (1500 RPM) for less than 1 minute to quickly bring the catalyst to efficient operating temperature. The RPM will reduce to idle once the temperature is achieved. This is normal engine operation under cold start conditions.
You can drive the vehicle during AWS activation, no need to wait.
This heats up the catalytic converter faster to reduce emissions and allows Mazda to use an exhaust header on the engine (to improve efficiency and horsepower).

Section.Name: Break In Period
Section.TextContent: BREAK-IN PERIOD
No special break-in is necessary, but a few precautions in the first 600 miles should be observed.
• Do not race the engine.
• Do not maintain one constant speed, either slow or fast, for a long period of time.
• Avoid full-throttle starts.
• Avoid unnecessary hard stops.
• Do not drive constantly at full-throttle or high engine rpm for extended periods of time.

Section.Name: Fuel Economy
Section.TextContent: FUEL ECONOMY

HotSpot.TextContent: Visit www.http://fueleconomy.gov for more information.

Section.TextContent: To achieve the best fuel economy:
• Drive sensibly. Speeding, rapid acceleration and excessive braking will lower fuel economy.
• Observe the speed limit. Fuel economy can decrease rapidly at speeds above 60 mph.
• Keep tires properly inflated. Under-inflated tires will lower fuel economy.
• Use the recommended grade of oil specified in the owner’s manual and keep the engine properly maintained. Visit your Authorized Mazda Dealer who specializes in the servicing of Mazda engines.
• Monitor the Current Fuel Economy. The current fuel economy is calculated every 2 seconds.
Additional items that also help increase fuel economy:
• Remove excess weight. Heavy items in the vehicle will lower fuel economy.
• Avoid excessive idling. Idling for long periods will waste gas.
• Use cruise control. Using cruise control on the highway helps to maintain a constant speed and saves gas.
• Use overdrive gears. Using overdrive gearing reduces the vehicle’s engine speed, which saves gas and reduces engine wear.
• Use a quality gasoline with the recommended octane. Use of higher octane gasoline will not improve your fuel economy.

Section.Name: Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS)
Section.TextContent: TIRE PRESSURE MONITORING SYSTEM (TPMS)

HotSpot.TextContent: The TPMS increases safety by notifying you when your vehicle's tire pressure is starting to get low. By helping you maintain proper tire pressure, the system:
• Improves vehicle handling
• Decreases tire wear
• Reduces braking distance
• Improves fuel economy

Section.TextContent: What is TPMS? Select the TPMS indicator light below.

HotSpot.TextContent: For your safety, the Mazda CX-5 is equipped with TPMS that detects low tire pressure in one or more tires. If the tire pressure starts getting low in one or more tires, the system alerts the driver by turning on a light in the instrument cluster and sounding an alarm.

Section.TextContent: What to do?

HotSpot.TextContent: Don’t ignore the TPMS warning light. Stop and check your tire pressure (when tires are cold) and inflate them to the proper pressure. Tire pressure specification can be found on the door jam label. Properly inflated tires are safer, last longer, and increase fuel economy.

Section.TextContent: Reset Procedure. Select the TPMS SET switch.

HotSpot.TextContent: In the following cases, the TPMS must be “initialized” so the system can operate normally.
• The tire pressure is adjusted (up or down) in one or more tires.
• A tire rotation is performed.
• Any tire or wheel is replaced.
• The vehicle’s battery is disconnected, replaced or completely dead.
Initialization Process (TPMS Warning Light is Illuminated):
1 Park the vehicle in a safe place and firmly apply the parking brake.
2 Let the tires cool, then adjust the tire pressure to the specified pressure (See tire label located on the driver’s side door jam area) on all four (4) tires.
3 Switch the ignition ON, but leave the vehicle parked.
4 Push and hold the TPMS “Set Switch” (left side of dash) until the TPMS warning light in the instrument cluster flashes twice and a beep sound is heard once.

If the TPMS “Set Switch” is pushed without adjusting the tire pressure, the system cannot detect the normal tire pressure. The TPMS warning light may not turn on, even if the tire pressure is low, or it may turn on if the tire pressure is normal.
Drastic changes in temperature or altitude may cause the TPMS warning light to turn on.

Section.Name: Power Seats
Section.TextContent: FRONT SEATS
Headrest

HotSpot.TextContent: For your safety, the front seats are equipped with active headrests that are not adjustable forward or backward, only up and down. An active headrest is designed to move forward in the event of a collision to close the gap between your head and the headrest (to prevent whiplash).

Section.TextContent: Power Seat Controls

HotSpot.TextContent: Seat Slide.
Move switch front or back and hold it.
Seat Height
Move switch up or down and hold it.
Front Height Adjustment of Seat Bottom
Raise or lower the front of the switch.
Seat Slide.
Move switch front or back and hold it.
Seat Height
Move switch up or down and hold it.
Front Height Adjustment of Seat Bottom
Raise or lower the front of the switch.
Seat Recline
Move the front or rear side of the reclining switch.
Seat Recline
Move the front or rear side of the reclining switch.
Lumbar Support
To increase firmness, press and hold the front part of the switch to the desired position and release it. Press the rear part of the switch to decrease firmness.

Section.TextContent: FRONT SEAT WARMER
Select the hotspot below for seat warmer operation.

HotSpot.TextContent: The driver and front passenger seats can be warmed by pushing the applicable seat warmer button while the ignition is ON.
Seat temperature increases with the number of illuminated indicator lights:
0 - OFF
1 - Low
2 - Mid
3 - High

Section.Name: Manual Seats
Section.TextContent: Manual Seat Controls

HotSpot.TextContent: Seat Slide Release Lever.
Pull lever up to move seat backward or forward.
Seat Height Adjustment Lever.
Raise or lower seat height by repeatedly pulling up or by pushing down on the lever.
Seat Recline Lever.
Pull up to adjust seatback angle.

Section.TextContent: REAR SEATS
Fold Down Rear Seats. Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: 1. Support the seatback with your hand.
2. Push the rear seatback knob down (red indicator is visible when the seat is in the unlocked position).
3. Bring the seatback forward.

Section.TextContent: Fold Down Rear Seats Using Remote Handle. Select the hotspots below.

HotSpot.TextContent: Select the hotspots below.
Folding Left and Center Seatbacks Down
1 Check that the rear seats are clear.
2 Open the liftgate and pull the outter remote handle lever.
4-2-4 rear seats are shown.
Folding Only Center Seatback Down
1 Store center seat head restraint.
2 Check that the rear seats are clear.
3 Open the liftgate and pull only the smaller of the left side remote handle levers.
Select the hotspot below.
Folding Right Seatback Down
1 Check that the rear seats are clear.
2 Open the liftgate and pull the right side remote handle lever.
4-2-4 rear seats are shown.

For tall drivers and front passengers who adjust the front seats all the way back, the headrests on the rear seats need to be removed when folding the rear seatbacks down. If not removed, the rear headrest will press into the front seatback. In order to remove the headrest from the rear seat, the seatback needs to be tilted slightly forward.

Section.Name: Infotainment System
Section.TextContent: Available on Sport with Bluetooth Audio Package.
INFOTAINMENT SYSTEM
The infotainment system by Mazda is designed to be operated by using one of the following two interfaces:
1 The Audio Buttons

HotSpot.TextContent: • In the interest of safety and to avoid distracted driving voice control to operate the infotainment system.

Section.TextContent: 2 Voice command

HotSpot.TextContent: Voice commands is activated by pressing the TALK button on the steering wheel and speaking a command.

Audio operation and media selection can be done using voice. Push the "Talk" button, wait for a beep, then say a command in a clear, natural voice (not too fast or too slow). A list of available commands will be displayed on the screen, and if you do not say anything, the system will read the commands. Commands will only work when in the correct mode (Radio, CD, BT, USB, or Pandora). To change modes, push the "Talk" button and say "Change mode." Some commands are listed below.
Some common voice commands:
• Radio: Seek up/down, Preset #
• CD: Play track #
• BT: Next/Previous folder
• CD, USB, BT: Play, Repeat, Shuffle
• CD, USB, BT, Pandora: Pause, Resume
• Pandora: Skip song, Thumbs up/down

Section.Name: Voice Command
Section.TextContent: Available on Sport with Bluetooth Audio Package.
VOICE COMMAND

HotSpot.TextContent: The voice command system increases safety while driving by reducing distractions. Use your voice to control the following functions:
• Audio
• Navigation
• Hands-free telephone

Section.TextContent: Select the hotspot below for Voice Command operation.

HotSpot.TextContent: Voice control is activated by pressing the TALK button on the steering wheel and speaking a command.

Audio operation and media selection can be done using voice. Push the "Talk" button, wait for a beep, then say a command in a clear, natural voice (not too fast or too slow). A list of available commands will be displayed on the screen, and if you do not say anything, the system will read the commands. Commands will only work when in the correct mode (Radio, CD, BT, USB, or Pandora). To change modes, push the "Talk" button and say "Change mode." Some commands are listed below.
Some common voice commands:
• Radio: Seek up/down, Preset #
• CD: Play track #
• BT: Next/Previous folder
• CD, USB, BT: Play, Repeat, Shuffle
• CD, USB, BT, Pandora: Pause, Resume
• Pandora: Skip song, Thumbs up/down
Some Useful Navigation Commands:
Setting a Destination
• Directions to an address
• Directions to the city center
• Nearest (brandname)
• Nearest (POI-category)
• Drive to Home
• Navigate to recent destination
Guidance Commands
• Plan Alternative
• Avoid roadblock
• Traffic Information
• Mute
• Repeat instruction
• 2D map
• 3D map
• Travel via ...
• Clear Route
Other Commands
• Where am I
• Add Favorite
• Report speed camera
• Mark map error
• Zoom in/out

Section.Name: Bluetooth
Section.TextContent: Not available on Sport with M/T
BLUETOOTH®

HotSpot.TextContent: Bluetooth® technology allows you to stay safely connected while driving. With many states banning cell phone use while driving, Bluetooth® lets you enjoy certain functions of your device without taking your hands off the steering wheel.

Section.TextContent: Pairing Your Bluetooth® Phone or Audio Device
Select your audio unit.

HotSpot.TextContent: • For safety reasons, you cannot pair a phone while driving.
• Before pairing your cell phone or audio device, you must manually turn on the device’s Bluetooth® function. Refer to the owner’s manual for your device.
• For customer service, contact the Customer Care Center at 800-430-0153 (Toll-free call).
• For device compatibility, go to:
1. Website: www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth
2. MyMazda App > MAZDA CONNECT
• IMPORTANT: Set the volume level on your cell phone or audio device to the highest level before distortion starts, then adjust the volume on the vehicle’s audio system.
• When in range of another Wi-Fi device, the Bluetooth connection between your phone and the system may disconnect for a short time if you have Wi-Fi enabled Turn off Wi-Fi on your phone if needed.
1 Manually turn Bluetooth on your phone or audio device.
2 Push and release the phone pick-up button on the steering wheel (wait for beep).
3 From main menu, say, “Setup,” then “Pairing Options.”
4 Say, “Pair.”
5 Say a four-digit code (i.e., “1, 2, 3, 4”).
6 Place phone in discovery mode; if necessary, consult your phone’s manual or go to www.mazdausa.com/bluetooth. Select model, Bluetooth, and follow screen prompts.
7 After phone is recognized, you will be prompted to name the paired phone.
To Make or Receive a Hands-Free Call:
PICK UP button: To make/receive/swap a call.
HANG UP button: To end/reject a call.
TALK button: To skip vehicle voice guidance and allow user to speak next voice command.
• Automatic Bluetooth Reconnection: On engine start, the last connected device will automatically be reconnected after several seconds. To switch phones, go to Device Settings and select Bluetooth.

Some phone models do not support all features. If your phone or device does not pair, please visit www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth, MyMazda App > MAZDA CONNECT, or contact (800) 430-0153 for further assistance or to report a phone/audio device concern.

• For connection issues, please confirm the Bluetooth connection status by making sure there is cell phone icon on the audio display (without infotainment) or by making sure there is a battery and signal strength icon in the top right corner of the screen (with infotainment). Some phones will turn off the Bluetooth signal after connecting the USB cable to the vehicle or after downloading an update.
- If not displayed, check your phone and make sure Bluetooth is turned on (or discoverable) in the Settings menu. Detailed instructions for some phones are available online.

- If there is still no connection, delete the pairing data on the system and your phone and try again after confirming your cell phone is compatible at www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth, or MyMazda App > MAZDA CONNECT.
• For safety reasons, you cannot pair a phone while driving.
• Before pairing your cell phone or audio device, you must manually turn on the device’s Bluetooth® function. Refer to the owner’s manual for your device.
• For customer service, contact the Customer Care Center at 800-430-0153 (Toll-free call).
• For device compatibility, go to:
1. Website: www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth
2. MyMazda App > MAZDA CONNECT
• IMPORTANT: Set the volume level on your cell phone or audio device to the highest level before distortion starts, then adjust the volume on the vehicle’s audio system.
• When in range of another Wi-Fi device, the Bluetooth connection between your phone and the system may disconnect for a short time if you have Wi-Fi enabled Turn off Wi-Fi on your phone if needed.
1 Manually turn Bluetooth on your phone or audio device.
2 Select Phone button.
3 Touch the "Setup" on-screen button.
4 Touch the "Bluetooth Setup" on-screen button. The list of all paired devices is displayed.
5 Touch the "Add New Device" on-screen button to display the message and switch to the device operation.
6 Using the device, perform a search for the Bluetooth® device (Peripheral device).
7 Select “Mazda” from the device list searched by the device.
8 Your phone will pair using one of the two ways:
• Input the displayed 4-digit code.
• Verify the displayed 6-digit.
9 (Call History) Incoming/Outgoing history for the device is downloaded automatically as well as your Phonebook.
10 (Devices compatible with SMS (Short Message Service) and MMS (Multimedia Message Service), messages are downloaded automatically. Permission may be required, depending on the mobile device.
To Make or Receive a Hands-Free Call:
PICK UP button: To make/receive/swap a call.
HANG UP button: To end/reject a call.
TALK button: To skip vehicle voice guidance and allow user to speak next voice command.
• Automatic Bluetooth Reconnection: On engine start, the last connected device will automatically be reconnected after several seconds. To switch phones, go to Device Settings and select Bluetooth.

Some phone models do not support all features. If your phone or device does not pair, please visit www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth, MyMazda App > MAZDA CONNECT, or contact (800) 430-0153 for further assistance or to report a phone/audio device concern.

• For connection issues, please confirm the Bluetooth connection status by making sure there is cell phone icon on the audio display (without infotainment) or by making sure there is a battery and signal strength icon in the top right corner of the screen (with infotainment). Some phones will turn off the Bluetooth signal after connecting the USB cable to the vehicle or after downloading an update.
- If not displayed, check your phone and make sure Bluetooth is turned on (or discoverable) in the Settings menu. Detailed instructions for some phones are available online.
- If there is still no connection, delete the pairing data on the system and your phone and try again after confirming your cell phone is compatible at www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth.

Section.Name: Phone
Section.TextContent: Not available on Sport with M/T
PHONE
Phone Features

To Make or Receive a Hands-Free Call:
PICK UP button: To make/receive/swap a call.
HANG UP button: To end/reject a call.
TALK button: To skip vehicle voice guidance and allow user to speak next voice command.
• Automatic Bluetooth Reconnection: On engine start, the last connected device will automatically be reconnected after several seconds. To switch phones, go to Device Settings and select Bluetooth.

Some phone models do not support all features. If your phone or device does not pair, please visit www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth, MyMazda App > MAZDA CONNECT, or contact (800) 430-0153 for further assistance or to report a phone/audio device concern.

• For connection issues, please confirm the Bluetooth connection status by making sure there is cell phone icon on the audio display (without infotainment) or by making sure there is a battery and signal strength icon in the top right corner of the screen (with infotainment). Some phones will turn off the Bluetooth signal after connecting the USB cable to the vehicle or after downloading an update.
- If not displayed, check your phone and make sure Bluetooth is turned on (or discoverable) in the Settings menu. Detailed instructions for some phones are available online.
- If there is still no connection, delete the pairing data on the system and your phone and try again after confirming your cell phone is compatible at www.MazdaUSA.com/bluetooth.

Section.Name: Navigation Controls
Section.TextContent: Available on Touring with Technology Package
Available on Grand Touring with Technology Package
NAVIGATION

HotSpot.TextContent: The vehicle’s navigation system increases safety by providing turn-by-turn navigation while driving, allowing you to concentrate on the road.

Section.TextContent: Navigation Home Screen
Tap the the screen to display the main menu.

HotSpot.TextContent: You can navigate to any of the following places using your voice:
• An address, including home
• Favorites
• Cities and towns
• POI (Point of Interest) categories
• POIs for named brands of, for example, restaurants, gas stations, car rental and gyms.
• A recent destination
To plan a route to an address using your voice, do the following:
1 Push the TALK button on the steering wheel.
2 When you hear the tone, you can say, for example “Drive to an address”.
3 Say the full address (without zip code) for your destination, for example “123 Main St., Los Angeles, California”. The system does not recognize zip codes.
• For best results, say the full address without pausing between words.
• Voice guidance can be skipped by pushing the talk button.
4 Say “Yes” if the address is correct. If shown a list of addresses, say the list number for the correct address or say “none of these”.
• While driving your vehicle, you can enter a destination address using your voice, but you cannot enter a destination using the keyboard.
• While driving your vehicle, the vehicle speed and the maximum speed limit (for most roads) can be seen on the bottom left tabs of the Navigation screen.
• Voice guidance can be skipped by pushing the talk button.
• Refer to the Navigation System Owner's Manual for additional navigation system details or visit www.mazdausa.com/navigation.
Some Useful Navigation Voice Commands:
Setting a Destination
• Directions to an address
• Directions to the city center
• Nearest (brandname)
• Nearest (POI-category)
• Drive to Home
• Navigate to recent destination
Guidance Commands
• Plan Alternative
• Avoid roadblock
• Traffic Information
• Mute
• Repeat instruction
• 2D map
• 3D map
• Travel via ...
• Clear Route
Other Commands
• Where am I
• Add Favorite
• Report speed camera
• Mark map error
• Zoom in/out

Section.Name: Navigation SD Card
Section.TextContent: Available on Touring with Technology Package
Available on Grand Touring with Technology Package
Navigation Data SD Card

Navigation map data is stored in the SD card. Updates are available for download by inserting the MAP SD card into a computer that is connected to the internet. Select the hotspot below for removal instructions.

HotSpot.TextContent: • Visit www.mazdausa.com/navigation within 60 days of vehicle delivery and download the most recent map available for your device for free. In order to download or update your map, the TomTom Home software must be downloaded. Please refer to the Navigation System Owners Manual section of www.mazdausa.com/ navigation for additional information.
• Only use your MAP SD card for operating and updating your navigation system. Do not insert the MAP SD card into another vehicle or into any other device such as a camera.
• Do not put other SD cards in this slot.
• If your vehicle is not equipped with a factory navigation system, your audio system can be upgraded to include navigation. Contact your Authorized Mazda Dealer for more details..
To Remove or Insert the MAP SD CARD (to update the map database):
1 Turn the vehicle ignition OFF.
2 Locate the MAP SD CARD door on the lower left side of the dash and swing it open downward.
3 Locate the MAP SD CARD sliding door and slide it to the right.
• Remove card: Push the card once, then pull it out.
• Insert card: Push the card in (label-side up), then close the sliding cover.

Section.Name: Infotainment System Settings
Section.TextContent: Available on Sport with Bluetooth Audio Package.
INFOTAINMENT SYSTEM SETTINGS
Select a hotspot to view the settings for each item.

HotSpot.TextContent: This screen is used to adjust the settings of the Infotainment Display.
This screen is used to adjust the settings of the audio's sound system.
This screen is used to adjust the settings of the vehicle's safety systems.
This screen is used to set the language of the Infotainment system.
This screen is used to restore the Infotainment system factory settings.
If there is a scroll bar on the right side, there are more items further down.

Section.Name: Clock Setting
Section.TextContent: SETTING THE CLOCK
Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: Push the H button to set the hour.
Push the M button to set the minutes.
Push the :00 button to reset the clock to the nearest hour.

Section.Name: Smart City Brake Support Support (SCBS)
Section.TextContent: Available on Touring with Technology Package
Available on Grand Touring with Technology Package
SMART CITY BRAKE SUPPORT (SCBS) SYSTEM

HotSpot.TextContent: The SCBS system reduces vehicle damage by applying the brakes when it determines that a collision with an object ahead of you is unavoidable.

Section.TextContent: What is SCBS? Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: The SCBS system is designed to reduce damage in the event of a collision by applying the brakes when the system’s laser sensor detects a vehicle ahead. The system operates when the vehicle speed is 2 to 18 mph (4 to 30 km/h) and the system determines that a collision with a vehicle ahead is unavoidable.
• It may be possible to avoid a collision if the relative speed between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is less than 9 mph (15 km/h).

• When the driver depresses the brake pedal while the system is in the operation range between 2 to 18 mph (4 to 30 km/h), the brakes are applied firmly and quickly to assist. (SCBS Automatic Brake is displayed in the active driving display)
• SCBS automatic brake is released approximately 2 seconds after the vehicle comes to a stop.
• Refer to your Owner’s Manual for complete details.
SCBS is only a supplementary system to reduce damage in the event of a collision, however the SCBS has limitations. Do not rely solely on the SCBS. Always keep your eyes on the road.
SCBS system can be turned off using the TCS OFF button.

Section.Name: Blind Spot Monitoring (BSM)
Section.TextContent: Available on Touring and Grand Touring
BLIND SPOT MONITORING (BSM)

HotSpot.TextContent: The BSM system helps reduce the chance of a collision by alerting you of vehicle(s) in your blind spots.

Section.TextContent: What is BSM? Select a hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: The BSM system is designed to assist the driver by monitoring blind spots on both sides of the vehicle to the rear in certain situations such as when changing lanes on roads and freeways.

Turning the BSM system off will turn off both the light and sound indicators. To manually turn the BSM system off, push the BSM OFF switch on the dash. The BSM OFF indicator in the instrument cluster will turn on to indicate when the BSM system is off. The BSM system will automatically turn on the next time the vehicle is started.
• If your vehicle speed is 7 mph (11 km/h) or more, the BSM will warn you of vehicles in the detection area by illuminating the BSM warning lights located on the left and right door mirrors.
• If you operate a turn signal in the direction of an illuminated BSM warning light, the system will also warn you with a beep and warning light flash.

• BSM sensors are located under the left and right rear bumper areas. The BSM system may not operate properly if the rear bumper gets dirty, so keep the rear bumper area clean and free of bumper stickers.

• BSM sensors are located under the left and right rear bumper areas. The BSM system may not operate properly if the rear bumper gets dirty, so keep the rear bumper area clean and free of bumper stickers.
• The BSM can assist the driver in confirming the safety of the surroundings, but is not a complete substitute.
• The driver is responsible for ensuring safe lane changes and other maneuvers.
• Always pay attention to the direction in which the vehicle is traveling and the vehicle’s surroundings.
• The BSM does not operate when the vehicle speed is lower than about 7 mph (11 km/h).

BSM is only a supplementary system to help aid in monitoring blind spots, however BSM has limitations. The system may not detect all vehicles, especially a motorcycle. Do not rely solely on the BSM. Relying solely on the BSM may cause an unexpected accident resulting in death or serious injury. Make sure to look over your shoulder before changing lanes.

Section.Name: Adaptive Front Lighting System
Section.TextContent: Available on Touring with Technology Package
Available on Grand Touring with Technology Package
ADAPTIVE FRONT-LIGHTING SYSTEM (AFS)

HotSpot.TextContent: The AFS increases night driving safety by increasing your visibility around curves.

Section.TextContent: What is AFS? Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: The AFS automatically turns the headlight beam to the right or left (in conjunction with the direction of the steering wheel) to improve the direction of headlight illumination while cornering. AFS only works when the vehicle is moving.
• With AFS, it is normal to see the headlights move and hear the sound of the headlight leveling motors at the front of the vehicle when the ignition is ON.
• The system will need to be reset if the vehicle battery has been disconnected or the system fuse has been replaced. Refer to your Owner’s Manual for easy to follow resetting instructions.
Push AFS OFF to turn system off or on. When off, the AFS OFF indicator in the instrument panel will turn on.

Section.Name: Lighting Controls
Section.TextContent: LIGHTING CONTROL/TURN SIGNAL LEVER

HotSpot.TextContent: Pull to flash high beams.
Push for high beams on.
Push for high beams on.
The light sensor automatically determines when to turn the headlights on or off.
The light sensor automatically determines when to turn the headlights on or off.
Turns tail, parking, and dashboard lights on.
Turns tail, parking, dashboard, and headlights on.
Turns tail, parking, dashboard, and headlights on.
Turns fog lights on only when headlights are on.
Turns fog lights on only when headlights are on.
Three-Flash Turn Signal: To signal a lane change, push the turn signal lever up or down halfway and release. The turn signal indicator will flash three times.

Section.Name: Three-Flash Turn Signal
Section.TextContent: THREE-FLASH TURN SIGNAL

Three-Flash Turn Signal allows you to flash the turn lights three times only. To signal a lane change, move the turn signal lever up or down halfway and release. The turn signal indicator will flash three times.

Section.Name: Windshield Wipers
Section.TextContent: WINDSHIELD WIPER/WASHER CONTROL LEVER

HotSpot.TextContent: Pull to dispense windshield washer fluid.
Pull to dispense windshield washer fluid.
AUTO Wipers: The rain sensor senses the amount of rainfall and turns the wipers on or off. Rotate the inner ring to adjust the sensitivity of the wipers.
AUTO Wipers: The rain sensor senses the amount of rainfall and turns the wipers on or off. Rotate the inner ring to adjust the sensitivity of the wipers.
AUTO wipers more sensitive (requires less rain to turn wipers on).
AUTO wipers less sensitive (requires more rain to turn wipers on).
Windshield MIST
Wiper OFF
Wiper AUTO
Wiper LO
Wiper HI
Rear Wiper INT (intermittent)
Rear Wiper ON
Rear Wiper MIST
Vehicles not equipped with AUTO wipers will have INT wipers. Set the lever to INT and choose an interval timing by rotating the ring between fast and slow.
If the ignition is ON, turn the AUTO wipers OFF when going through a car wash, or while cleaning or touching the windshield.

Section.Name: Climate Control
Section.TextContent: CLIMATE CONTROL

Section.Name: Audio Controls
Section.TextContent: AUDIO CONTROLS
Select your audio unit.

HotSpot.TextContent: Audio operation and media selection can be done using voice. Push the “TALK” button on the steering wheel, wait for a beep, then say a command in a clear, natural voice (not too fast or too slow). Some common commands are listed below.
Play (and any of the following):
AM, FM, CD, Bluetooth, Pandora, USB, AUX
Play or Resume / Pause or Stop / Next or Previous
Play (and any of the following):
Song, Playlist (playlist name), Artist (artist name), Album (album name), Genre (genre name), Folder (folder name)
Tune to Station (frequency AM or FM)
Tune to Channel Number (XM)
Gracenote Update

The Gracenote media database is used to improve voice recognition of artist and album names with the Mazda Hands Free system. To make best use of the voice recognition, install the most recent database.
1 Load the Gracenote update on a memory stick from www.MazdaUSA.com/USB. Insert the memory stick into the USB port.
2 Go to System Settings in the infotainment system.
3 Select Music Database Update.

Section.Name: AUX/USB
Section.TextContent: Audio USB / AUX Inputs / 12V Accessory Socket

Your vehicle is equipped with a USB port and auxiliary AUX jack located in the center console. This will allow you to play your iPod, USB device, or portable audio player through the vehicle’s audio system. Learn the system when parked and do not let it distract you while driving.

HotSpot.TextContent: IMPORTANT:
• Set the volume level on your portable audio player to the highest level before distortion starts, then use the vehicle’s audio system to adjust the volume.

• Unplug any device from the USB port and accessory socket before turning off the vehicle. Leaving devices plugged in can drain the battery and cause issues during the Bluetooth pairing process at startup. Wait about 15 seconds after starting the vehicle before plugging anything into the USB port.
USB Port
1 Locate the USB port inside the center console.
2 Connect the device plug into the portable audio player and into the USB port.
3 Turn the vehicle audio system on.
4 Audio Controls:
without infotainment: Push the USB/AUX button on the audio unit to switch to the USB mode.
with infotainment: Select AUDIO button on the audio system, then touch the "USB" on-screen button.
5 Use the vehicle’s audio system or steering wheel controls to control the connected USB device.
When using a USB memory stick, the system plays the first audio file when restarting the vehicle. It does not not start where it left off when turning off the engine.
USB Port
1 Locate the USB port inside the center console.
2 Connect the device plug into the portable audio player and into the USB port.
3 Turn the vehicle audio system on.
4 Audio Controls:
without infotainment: Push the USB/AUX button on the audio unit to switch to the USB mode.
with infotainment: Select AUDIO button on the audio system, then touch the "USB" on-screen button.
5 Use the vehicle’s audio system or steering wheel controls to control the connected USB device.
When using a USB memory stick, the system plays the first audio file when restarting the vehicle. It does not not start where it left off when turning off the engine.
AUX Jack
1 Locate the AUX jack inside the center console.
2 Connect the device plug into the portable audio player and into the AUX jack.
3 Turn the vehicle audio system on.
4 Audio Controls:
without infotainment: Push the USB/AUX button on the audio unit to switch to the AUX mode.
with infotainment: Select AUDIO button on the audio system, then touch the "AUX" on-screen button.
5 Use the portable audio player controls to play music.
You will need an audio cable with an 1/8 inch (3.5 mm) mini stereo plug (available as a Genuine Mazda accessory) to connect your portable audio player into the aux jack.
12 Volt Accessory Socket
The accessory socket in the dash is on with ignition on and the accessory socket in the center console is always on.
When using the accessory socket in the center console, make sure to disconnect any device from it when turning off the ignition, otherwise the vehicle’s battery could go dead.
12 Volt Accessory Socket
The accessory socket in the dash is on with ignition on and the accessory socket in the center console is always on.
When using the accessory socket in the center console, make sure to disconnect any device from it when turning off the ignition, otherwise the vehicle’s battery could go dead.
12 Volt Accessory Socket
The accessory socket in the dash is on with ignition on and the accessory socket in the center console is always on.
When using the accessory socket in the center console, make sure to disconnect any device from it when turning off the ignition, otherwise the vehicle’s battery could go dead.

Section.Name: Instrument Cluster

MetaData.keyword: Air Bag Front Seat Belt Pretensioner System

Section.TextContent: INSTRUMENT CLUSTER

Section.Name: Multi-Information Display
Section.TextContent: MULTI-INFORMATION DISPLAY
Select the information display type below.

HotSpot.TextContent: Select the hotspot below.
Toggle the INFO button up or down on the steering wheel to display available functions.
Select hotspots for additional information.
Distance to empty
This mode displays the approximate distance you can travel on the remaining fuel based on the fuel economy. The distance-to-empty will be calculated and displayed every second.
Current MPG
This mode displays the current fuel economy by calculating the amount of fuel consumption and the distance traveled. Current fuel economy will be calculated and displayed every 2 seconds.
Average Speed

This mode displays the average vehicle speed by calculating the distance and the time traveled since connecting the battery or resetting the data. Average vehicle speed will be calculated and displayed every 10 seconds.
Average MPG

This mode displays the average fuel economy by calculating the total fuel consumption and the total traveled distance since purchasing the vehicle, reconnecting the battery after disconnection, or resetting the data. The average fuel economy is calculated and displayed every minute.
Settings
Customize the following vehicle functions.
• Reset Averages
• Smart City Brake
• Blind Spot Monitoring
• Maintenance
• Optional Screen
• Volumes
• Units
• Restore Defaults
Select the hotspot below.
Toggle the INFO button up or down on the steering wheel to display available functions.
Select hotspots for additional information.
Average Speed

This mode displays the average vehicle speed by calculating the distance and the time traveled since connecting the battery or resetting the data. Average vehicle speed will be calculated and displayed every 10 seconds.
Current MPG
This mode displays the current fuel economy by calculating the amount of fuel consumption and the distance traveled. Current fuel economy will be calculated and displayed every 2 seconds.
Average MPG

This mode displays the average fuel economy by calculating the total fuel consumption and the total traveled distance since purchasing the vehicle, reconnecting the battery after disconnection, or resetting the data. The average fuel economy is calculated and displayed every minute.
Distance to empty
This mode displays the approximate distance you can travel on the remaining fuel based on the fuel economy. The distance-to-empty will be calculated and displayed every second.

Section.Name: Manual Shift Mode
Section.TextContent: MANUAL SHIFT MODE

HotSpot.TextContent: Manual Shift Mode gives you the feel of driving a manual transmission. By allowing you to shift manually, you control the engine rpm and torque.

Section.TextContent: What is Manual Shift Mode? Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: Manual Shift Mode gives you the feel of driving a manual transmission by allowing you to manually shift to control engine rpm and torque when more control is desired.
Steering Shift Switches can be used in “D” or “M”.
To Use Manual Shift Mode:
• Shift the lever from D to M.
To Shift Down To A Lower Gear:
Tap the shift lever forward (-) once.
To Shift Up To A Higher Gear:
Tap the shift lever back (+) once.

Section.Name: Active Adaptive Shift
Section.TextContent: ACTIVE ADAPTIVE SHIFT (AAS) CONTROL

HotSpot.TextContent: The AAS system gives you better control and a more connected driving experience. The system automatically adjusts how and when the transmission shifts gears based on road conditions and your driving style.

Section.TextContent: What is AAS? Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: AAS will automatically adjust how and when the transmission shifts gears based on road conditions and your driving style. The transmission may stay in a lower gear longer than usual when going up or down hills or driving around corners. This feature gives you better control and a more connected driving experience.

Section.Name: Accelerator Pedal Kickdown Switch
Section.TextContent: ACCELERATOR PEDAL KICKDOWN SWITCH (A/T only)
What is Accelerator Pedal Kickdown Switch? Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: The accelerator pedal is equipped with a kickdown switch to give the driver more control and to improve fuel economy.

When you depress the accelerator 95% of the way, you will feel an increase in resistance. Push harder, and you will feel a click as you activate the kickdown switch. The transmission will usually downshift (depending on engine speed) and the engine will switch to maximum power mode. This kickdown switch function is the same in both Manual mode and in “D”.

Section.Name: Hill Launch Assist (HLA)
Section.TextContent: HILL LAUNCH ASSIST (HLA)

HotSpot.TextContent: The HLA system increases safety by helping you make smooth hill starts. Forward and backward rolling is reduced; making hill starts easier and more relaxed.

Section.TextContent: What is HLA? Select the hotspot below.

HotSpot.TextContent: HLA helps assist you when accelerating the vehicle from a stop while on a hill or slope. When the brake pedal is released and the accelerator pedal is pushed, HLA prevents the vehicle from rolling forward or backward. It operates on a downward slope when the shift lever is in the reverse (R) position, and on an upward slope when the shift lever is in a position other than the reverse (R) position.
IMPORTANT: The HLA system will hold the vehicle for a maximum of 2.0 seconds while the driver is changing from the brake pedal to the accelerator pedal.

Section.Name: Cup Holders
Section.TextContent: CUP HOLDERS
Select the hotspots below.
Front Cup Holders

HotSpot.TextContent: The front cup holders are located in the center console near the emergency brake handle.

When using the cup holder to hold a small sized cup (height about 100 mm (4 in)), the cup can be taken out of the cup holder easily by using the supplied spacer. The spacer can be set and used in either of the front cup holders.

Section.TextContent: Rear Cup Holders

HotSpot.TextContent: The rear cup holders are located on the rear center armrest.

Section.TextContent: Bottle Holders

HotSpot.TextContent: Bottle holders are located on the inside of the doors.

Section.Name: Interior Cleaning
Section.TextContent: INTERIOR CLEANING
Keep Your Mazda Clean. Select the hotspots below.

HotSpot.TextContent: Cloth Upholstery
Remove dust and loose dirt from the fabric with a whisk broom or vacuum cleaner. Then use a mild soap and water solution to clean the surface. For immediate spot removal, use a fabric spot cleaner.
Mazda cleaning supplies are available at your Mazda Dealer.
Floor Mats
Floor Mats should be cleaned with mild soap and water only (other products may make the mat slippery which could lead to an accident). Be sure to reinstall the mat securely after cleaning.
Infotainment
Use an extremely soft and clean material with mild detergent to remove soiling. Harsh rubbing can result in damage such as white scratch marks.
Instrument Panel Top
Use an extremely soft and clean material with mild detergent to remove soiling. Harsh rubbing can result in damage such as white scratch marks.
Lap/Sholder Belt
Use mild soap and water to clean the lap/sholder belt (DO NOT use bleach, etc. as this may weaken the material). After cleaning, let the belt dry thoroughly before letting it retract.
Leather Upholstery
To quickly and easily remove surface stains from your Mazda's leather, use our specially formulated cleaner. Follow directions on the packaging.
Mazda cleaning supplies are available at your Mazda Dealer.
Panels

Parts that are fitted with panels that need to be cleaned should be done with a soft cloth to wipe off dirt from the surface. Scratches or nicks resulting from a hard brush or cloth may not be repairable.
Window Interior
Use a glass cleaner and follow the directions on the container.
Mazda cleaning supplies are available at your Mazda Dealer.

Section.Name: Liftgate
Section.TextContent: LIFTGATE

For the hatchback, when the liftgate opener switch is pushed, the liftgate will open slightly. If the liftgate is not opened within 1.5 seconds, the liftgate latch locks (you will hear it lock) and the liftgate cannot be opened or closed from this slightly raised position. To open/close the liftgate, push the liftgate opener switch, open the liftgate within 1.5 seconds, then close it. The door/liftgate ajar warning light will be on if the liftgate is not fully closed.
